answers.author: Matthew Reges
answers.text:
Especially for smaller organizations, it's helpful to make use of valid data collected by other respected entities and combine it with your own staff observations. Your scorecard gains legitimacy when internal and external data point the same way.
Does your zoning office track and cite blighted vacant properties? That's a good measure of internal activity, but it describes staff, not properties. That measure will show a spike in blight If the inspections team prioritizes certain work or gets extra staff.
If you have a regional association of realtors, it may be a great source of data. Real estate data may include own/rent stats, valuations, sale activity, and vacancy. This data may be kept quite current with market activity and could be shared with your team. You can also ask local realtors about buying subscriptions to certain databases.
Census and BLS data are updated more slowly but give the most authoritative answers. Depending on the size and population of your districts, the Census gives a baseline and the three-year American Community Survey update provides a checkpoint.
Lastly, school systems collect a fair amount of population data which might be fragmented from your office. Student enrollment (and demographics) isn't the same as total population change, but it tells an important related story and is updated annually with a precise count.
Others can weigh in with specific examples and links. Our organization's nascent scorecard site is here at http://www.charlottesville.org/clearpoint.aspx

answers.author: David Collinsworth
answers.text:
Mercy - the City of Westerville has just put together a reporting mechanism to log and record department/process owner progress on strategic plan goals.  This reporting tool provides a baseline across the board measuring stick for the management team to monitor and evaluate strategic plan progress.  From that, our Community Affairs Administrator/PIO takes that and develops a more narrative summary with color and graphics that gets forwarded to our City Council and is made available to the public for their information. 
The strategic plan info. is available at the following link including our first quarterly update that went to Council 2 months ago.
http://www.westerville.org/index.aspx?page=742
We're still in the fine tuning stage but if you would like to contact our office for more information, feel free to call Christa Dickey at (614) 901-6411.

author: Mercy Montgomery
text:
We're in the process of re-assessing the methods and sources that inform our achievement of strategic goals in the hopes of effectively assessing goal achievement more regularly (ideally quarterly but at least biannually).
Does anyone have any experience regularly measuring goals similar to the following topics throughout the year? If so, what data sources (citizen surveys, sampling from existing data, etc) did you use to collect systematic data?
•Increase historic district home ownership to 40% 
•Decrease vacant residential structures by 30%  
•Increase urban population by 2% (1,200) 
Thanks!
Mercy Montgomery
City of Hamilton, OH
title: Strategic Goals Measurement: Tricky Percentages
